Company: Shandong Weishan Lake Rare Earth Co. Ltd.

Name: Gremyakha-Vyrmes
Commods: Fe, Ti, P, Zr, Nb, REE
REE_Mins: allanite-(Ce), ferriallanite-(Ce), ferriallanite-(La), fergusonite, chevkinite, pyrochlore
Sig_Mins: titanifeous magnetite, ilmenite, titanite, apatite, magnetite, zircon, chalcopyrite, astrophyllite, pyrrhotite, aenigmatite, pyrochlore, pentlandite, pyrite
Oth_Mins: albite, calcite, nepheline, cancrinite, chlorite, microcline, biotite, aegirine-augite, phlogopite, arfvedsonite, feldspar, olivine, prehnite, graphite
HAge_Ma: 1750 ± 40 Ma (K-Ar, biotite, urtite) to 1870 ± 40 Ma (K-Ar, nepheline, urtite)
Host_Lith: albitite, calcitic carbonatite, ijolite, urtite, peridotite, nepheline syenite
Comments: The REE-Zr-pyrochlore mineralization in the ijolite-urtite rocks may be metasomatic; Sorokhtina and others (2012) indicated that REE minerals mainly in albitite. Woolley and Kjarsgaard describe mineralization as cumulates in gabbro and wehrlite.

Comments: Fluorite-carbonate veins and stockworks 0.1–1.5 km long and 1.4–30 m thick. 0.2-1.93 percent TREO.

Name: Khiagda
Components: includes Istochnoye, Vershinnoye Dybrynskoye, Koretkondinskoye, Kolichikanskoye, Vershinnoye, Namaru and Tetrakhskoye orebodies
Oth_Mins: quartz, plagioclase, microcline, mica, clay, zeolite
Comments: REE is a potential byproduct of uranium mining at this site; deposit consists of 4 contiguous mineralized paleovalleys; the area has permafrost to depth of ~90 meters; mineralization is at depth of 90-280 m and is composed of 8 spatially associated ore bodies.
Ref_List: Porter Geoconsultancy (2014); Solodov (2014); World Nuclear News (2015)
P_Note: JSC Khiagda is planning to install a plant to extract REO (2015).

Name: Khibiny
Components: includes Apatity Circus, Koashva, Kukisvumchorr, Niorkpakhk, Partomchorr, Rasvumchorr and Yukspor deposits, Vostochny mine
Sig_Mins: apatite, pyrochlore, titanite, lamprophyllite, astrophyllite, strontianite, barite, zircon, titanifeous magnetite, vlasovite, wöhlerite, gittinsite, fluorite, cryolite, siderite, edingtonite, ilmenite
Oth_Mins: nepheline, calcite, ankerite, arfvedsonite, aegirine-augite, biotite, phlogopite, microcline, alkali feldspar, agrellite, dawsonite, nahcolite, aenigmatite
Host_Lith: ijolite, pyroxenite, peridotite, melilitolite, melteigite, carbonatite, pulaskite
Comments: Largest igneous apatite deposit in the world, in urtite-ijolite. REE minerals largely in alkaline rocks not carbonatite (Kogarko and others, 1995); apatite contains 9000-11000 ppm REE and 500-900 ppm Y. Small bodies of carbonatites contain as much as 9 percent REE, 6.5 percent Sr, 3 percent Ba.
Ref_List: Belolipetskii and Voloshin (1996); Castor (1994); Chernyi and others (2014); Hedrick and Templeton (1991); Kogarko and others (1995); Chakhmouradian (1996); Neary and Highley (1984); Pell (1996); Wall and Mariano (1996); Wall and Zaitsev (2004); Zaitsev (1996); Zaitsev and others (2002)

Name: Serra Verde
Loc_Note: Estimated location near town of Minacu.
Dep_Type: alkaline igneous with residual enrichment; supergene
Dep_Note: weathered crust elution-deposited REE, laterite, weathered alklaine igneous, ion adsorption
REE_Mins: monazite-(Ce), xenotime-(Y), bastnäsite, cerianite-(Ce), fergusonite, kaolinite
Company: Mineração Serra Verde (subsidiary of Mining Ventures Brasil, 2013)
Comments: 23% HREO in TREO of indicated resources; 1.8 billion-year-old Pela Ema granite with tin veins was intruded at depth about 540 Ma by alkaline rocks leading to potassium metasomatism and alteration; subsequent tropical weathering (10–70 Ma) led to 15-20 m thick lateritic plateau; about half of the REE in the ore is sorbed on clay.
Ref_List: Hatch (2015); Mineração Serra Verde (2014); Natural History Museum (2015); Rocha and others (2013); Santana and others (2015)

Sig_Mins: ilmenite, rutile, zircon, sillimanite, garnet, magnetite, tourmaline, thorianite
Comments: Byproduct of Ti mining; old beach deposit (1.2 m above sea level) and Modern beach. Deposit replenished by annual monsoon. Shipments suspended in 1997 due to rebellion, but looking to resume in 2003. Deposit is just over 7 km long and 0.6 km wide and is mined each year from south to north.

P_Note: 1) 700 t monazite produced from 1.963 Mt ore from 1966–1982; 2) 1003 t monazite produced from 1984–1985.
RR_oth_grd: 2) 56% ilmenite, 6.4–8% zircon, 6.4% rutile; 3) 1.141% ilmenite, 0.087% rutile, 0.024% zircon
